_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Closed circuit TV monitors/Operator Rounds at least twice a shift/distributive controls system
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: On-site Fire & Rescue Squad and HAZMAT Team/Trained Operators, Water Monitors and extinguishers around unit
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Distributive Control System / Operator Rounds several times/shift /Closed Circuit TV Monitors
_prev_prog_3.Description: The No 1 Sulfur Recovery Unit process is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  There are 12 elements of the PSM program which have been extended to satisfy EPA's Program Level 3 accident prevention program requirements where necessary.  These elements are Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractors, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Mechanical Integrity, Safe Work Practices, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, and Compliance Audits.  In addition to the 12 elements, this unit utilizes process controls such as relief valves, flares, automatic shutoffs, emergency air supply, backup pumps, grounding equipment, mitigating systems such as dikes, and operator routine checks to ensure safe operation.  The expected dates for completion of changes as a result of a PHA, audit, and incident investigation includes time for completing engineering work and/or the next scheduled shutdown/turnaround during which the work can be completed.

_prev_prog_3.Description: The No. 5 Crude Unit is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  There are 12 elements of the PSM program which have been extended to satisfy EPA's Program Level 3 Accident Prevention Program requirements where necessary.  These elements are Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractors, Pre-StartupSafety Review, Mechanical Integrity, Safe Work Practices, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, and Compliance Audits.  In addition to the 12 elements, this unit utilizes process controls such as relief valves, flares, automatic shutoffs, emergency air supply, backup pumps, grounding equipment, mitigating systems such as dikes, and operator routine checks to ensure safe operation.  The expected dates for completion of changes as a result of a PHA, audit, and incident investigation includes time for completing engineering work and/or the next scheduled shutdown/turnaround during which the work can be completed.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CATLETTSBURG REFINING, LLC

Risk Management Program Plan

November 2017





EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for its employees, the public, and the environment. Catlettsburg Refining, LLC's policy is to conduct activities so as to protect and promote the health and safety of its employees, customers, and others who may be affected by these activities, and to limit adverse effects on the physical environment in which its activities are carried out. As part of this policy, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has established systems to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility. One part of these systems is a Risk Management Program (RMP)that helps manage the risks at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC and that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) rule 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule). One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to resubmit its risk management plan (RMPlan) describing the Risk Management Program at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC every five (5) years, within 6 months of the startup of a unit requiring a revised PHA due to process changes, or prior to introducing a hazardous chemical in a new unit. This document is intended to satisfy the RMPlan Executive Summary requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC. 



On October 1, 2017, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC transferred ownership of certain logistics assets to a separate operating company, Catlettsburg Refining Logistics LLC.  Logistics assets transferred include various storage tanks, unloading/loading operations, and ancillary equipment.  Both Catlettsburg Refining, LLC and Catlettsburg Refining Logistics LLC are wholly-owned, indirect subsidiaries of Marathon Petroleum Corporation.  The refinery assets and the logistics assets owned by both co

mpanies remain a single stationary source.  There will be no changes to personnel or reporting structure for the operation of the transferred equipment. 



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is committed to the safety of its employees and the public, and to the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances. Key to this commitment is the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances in and around the refinery. Catlettsburg Refining, LLC utilizes engineering controls, inspection programs, and detailed procedures as means to prevent accidental releases. In the event of a release, the refinery has a well-trained emergency response team to contain, mitigate, monitor, and stop the release. The refinery has fully staffed and trained emergency response teams for firefighting (Fire and Rescue Squad), medical emergencies, oil spill response (Oil Spill Response Team), and ambient air monitoring (Air Monitoring Team). Catlettsburg Refining, LLC evaluates each situation, responds based on the particular circumstances, and if necessary, requests assistance from outside emergency responders, including local fire departments, in controlling and containing the release and to prevent and/or reduce the consequences of the release. Catlettsburg Refining, LLC, the local emergency planning committees (LEPCs), and the fire department have also established a system for warning the community if an accident occurs that could threaten the community.



The Catlettsburg Refining, LLC Division Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the risk management program at the facility. However, the specific responsibilities for certain aspects of that program have been delegated by the Manager to other personnel who report either directly, or through other management personnel, to the Manager. Those relationships are depicted on the facili

ty organization chart. Specific responsibility for the implementation of the Process Safety Management (PSM), the RMP hazard assessment and Risk Management Plan and Accident Prevention Program has been delegated to the Environmental, Safety and Security Manager. The facility emergency response program, including compliance with the RMP aspects of that effort, is also the responsibility of the Environmental, Safety and Security Manager. In keeping with our policy that safe operation is part of everyone's job, many other refinery personnel are also involved in RMP activities on an ongoing basis.



2. Regulated Substances



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is a full range refinery and petroleum products facility located in Catlettsburg, Kentucky. We use crude oil as our feed material and make a variety of petroleum-based products, including gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, asphalt, specialty chemicals, and liquefied petroleum gases such as propane and butane. Many of these products are flammable substances that the EPA has specifically listed in the RMP rule and are present in our process units above the EPA threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs. The covered units are listed in the RMP data included with this summary (Section 1.17 of the RMP Data Elements). 

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC handles two toxic substances, hydrofluoric acid (HF) and hydrogen sulfide (H2S), in sufficient quantity to be covered by the RMP rule. HF is used to make high quality gasoline components and H2S is produced during the removal of sulfur from products and refinery fuel gas. 



In 2013, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC began conversion of an out of service Aliphatics unit to become the Condensate Fractionation Unit.  The facility is planned to be completed and put into service in April or May 2015.  This 2015 RMP re-submission includes this new facility.



3. Accidental Release Prevention Program



The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at Catlettsburg Refining,

LLC.  The processes at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard. The OSHA PSM requirements are very similar to the EPA RMP requirements for refineries; therefore this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements. The PSM program at this facility has been extended by Catlettsburg Refining, LLC, where necessary, to satisfy EPA's Program Level 3 Accident Prevention Program requirements.



3.1 Employee Participation



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from development of the PSM/RMP program procedures and revisions, updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as members of Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) teams, incident investigation teams, and compliance audit teams. Employees have access to all information created as part of Catlettsburg Refining, LLC accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees are involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC and addresses each accident prevention program element. In addition, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has a number of initiatives under way that address process safety and personal safety issues. These initiatives include a Behavior Based Safety program, a Joint Union Management Team, the Safety Action Process, and the Responsible Care Program to promote both process and personal safety. The teams typically have members from various areas of the plant, including operations, maintenance, engineering, and plant management.



3.2 Process Safety Information



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents a

ddress chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific departments within Catlettsburg Refining, LLC are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. A table summarizing the reference documents and their locations is readily available as part of the written employee participation plan to help employees locate any necessary process safety information.  



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. For specific process areas, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, pressure, level, composition) in a Not-To-Exceed Limits Document. Catlettsburg Refining, LLC ensures that the process is maintained within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrumentation systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



3.3 Process Hazard Analysis



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has a comprehensive PHA program to help ensure that hazards associated wi

th the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage those hazards. 



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC primarily uses the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations. HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques available. Checklists are utilized to evaluate Human Factors and Facility Siting. The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise and a trained team leader. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.



The PHA team recommendations are forwarded to local management for resolution. Implementation of safety improvements in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. They ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive prompt attention. All approved safety improvements being implemented in response to PHA team recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each recommendation is documented and retained.



To help ensure that the controls put in place originally and those added as a result of the HAZOP do not eventually deviate significantly from the original safety intent, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC periodically updates and revalidates the PHA results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. Offsite effects have been considered in all PHAs completed after August 1996. The results and recommendations from these updates are documented and retained. Once again, th

e team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the recommendations is documented and retained.



3.4 Operating Procedures



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures are certified annually as current and accurate. Procedures are maintained current by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made to the process. In addition, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC operating procedures provide guidance on how to respond to events that result in exceeding safe operating limits for specific process or equipment parameters. The written operating procedures are readily available for all refinery personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.



3.5 Training



To complement the written procedures for process operations, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has implemented a company training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in Catlettsburg Refining, LLC operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests and skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained. This refresher training is conducted at a minimum of every 3 years. All of this training is documented for each ope

rator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.



3.6 Contractors



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC uses contractors to supplement its work force throughout the year, as well as during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform Catlettsburg Refining, LLC personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with access to (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, (4) safe work practices, and (5) a work permit process (i.e., for hot work, confined space, etc.) prior to their beginning work. A contractor safety meeting is conducted to communicate plant safety issues and policy changes, as well as allow contractors to provide feedback.  In addition, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor. Catlettsburg Refining, LLC personnel periodically monitors contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.



3.7 Pre-Startup Safety Reviews



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC conducts a pre-startup safety review for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifica

tions and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A review involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function.



3.8 Mechanical Integrity



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.



Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the processes on which they will be working, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner. Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service, or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.



Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance. Catlettsburg Refining, LLC incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and tha

t proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.



3.9 Safe Work Practices



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel into the refinery and process areas and units, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation and de-energization of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for mitigation of hazards before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a hot work permit and procedure to control welding and other spark-producing activities, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely. Revisions to safe work practices are made periodically as needed and workers are informed of and/or trained on the revised procedures.



3.10 Management of Change



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided with any necessary training on the change. Changes are tracked electronically and signoffs are documented and retained. Each change has a pre-startup safety review performed prior

to placing the change in service.



3.11 Incident Investigation



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or process related personnel injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and reviews these results with Catlettsburg Refining, LLC management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations. 



3.12 Compliance Audits



To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC periodically conducts audits to determine if procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years by a third party. Both hourly and management personnel participate during the audit. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to Catlettsburg Refining, LLC management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.



In 2008, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC underwent an OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) National Emphasis Program (NEP) Audit and no fines were incurred. In 2017, the

refinery underwent a Responsible Care Certification Audit and was re-certified as a Responsible Care facility.



4 Chemical-specific Prevention Steps



The processes at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC use chemicals that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program previously summarized is applied to all processes at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC. Collectively, these prevention program activities help reduce the likelihood of accidental releases occurring as a result of equipment failures or human errors involving toxic and/or flammable substances.



In addition to the accident prevention program activities, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:



4.1 Release Detection



* Chemical-specific detectors with alarms in selected areas including toxic chemical detectors in the Alkylation Unit and the Sulfur Recovery Units

* Closed circuit TV monitors in each of the control rooms including the Alkylation Unit

* Hydrogen sulfide detectors are worn by all personnel

* Air Monitoring Team



4.2 Release Containment/Control



* Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate process materials to prevent overpressure damage to equipment

* Scrubbers to neutralize chemical releases such as the fuel gas scrubbers to remove hydrogen sulfide

* Manual and automatic valves to permit isolation of the process

* Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)

* De-inventory system for the Alkylation unit

* Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases

* Redundant equipment and instrumentation where needed (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, redundant firewater pumps, etc.)

* Release mitigation systems (water spray systems)

* Fire suppress

ion and extinguishing systems throughout the refinery (e.g., at the solvent loading rack, propane bullets, and the FCC unit)

* Trained emergency response personnel

* Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)

* Several blast-resistant control buildings to help protect personnel and control systems



5 Five-year Accident History



As of the last RMP resubmission in 2015, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC had experienced three (3) accidents during the previous five years which met the EPA RMP reporting criteria.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC experienced an additional accident on 5/11/17 that met the EPA RMP reporting criteria.  The offsite evacuation and shelter-in-place actions that took place during this event were not coordinated with the refinery.  Air monitoring teams(AMTs) were deployed from the refinery during this incident.  Monitoring results by the AMTs in the community did not detect any readings that would have required any community evacuations or shelter-in-place actions.  Communications between members of the community and non-refinery personnel during the incident resulted in precautionary actions being taken without the refinery's knowledge or input.  Once AMT results were communicated from the refinery to the community, the evacuation and shelter-in-place actions were immediately discontinued.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC maintains a 5-year accident history that fulfills the requirements of the RMP rule.



6 Emergency Response Program



The Catlettsburg Refining, LLC maintains an emergency response plan to protect employee and public safety as well as the environment. The purpose of the emergency response plan is to minimize the impact on the refinery and surrounding areas in the event of an emergency situation. The plan consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The plan

also addresses severe weather conditions. The plan address all aspects of emergency response, including responsibilities of the Emergency Response Team, proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, refinery evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after the initiation of the response, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, the Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is reviewed and updated at least once a year.



The overall emergency response program for the Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is coordinated with the Boyd County, Kentucky LEPC/DES and Cabell/Wayne County, West Virginia LEPC and with offsite responders who would be called to support emergency response efforts if required. This coordination includes periodic meetings with the agencies, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. In addition, emergencies at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC are classified in one of three levels as specified by the Emergency Response plan. Level One emergencies involve minor incidents limited to the work site. Level Two emergencies involve incidents which will not have an offsite impact but will require the activation of the Incident Command system and the Emergency Response teams. Level Three emergencies involve incidents which could have an offsite impact and require the Incident Commander to contact the local fire departments (911 centers) and make a recommendation for public action. Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC/DES officials and

emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to participating in periodic LEPC/DES meetings, the Catlettsburg Refining, LLC conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC/DES and emergency response organizations, and the refinery provides refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the refinery. 



7 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Catlettsburg Refining, LLC continually strives to improve the safety of its operations through periodic safety reviews, the incident investigation program, and a program soliciting safety suggestions from the employees. Catlettsburg Refining, LLC resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process. The following types of changes are planned during the next 5 years:



* Continue implementation of Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) on critical pieces of equipment in covered units until completed.

* Attain OSHA's VPP certification

* Projects to raise underground lines

* Expansion of benzene removal from waste water

* Flare gas recovery project to compress and recover gases that are currently combusted in the refinery flare system

* Facility siting upgrades including control room relocations

* Siemens study for relief system improvements

* Fire water and HF Alky mitigation system upgrades

* Emergency isolation valve projects

* Sample station upgrades

* Safety shower/eye wash upgrades
